qas.question: Along with subjective experience, cognitive processes, expressive behavior and psychophysiological changes, what is another notable emotional component?
With what emotional component did William James identify emotion?
What emotional component did behaviorists identify emotion with?
What academics identified emotions with physiological changes?
Who discussed emotions in the context of expressive body actions and cultural labels?
Along with subjective experience, cognitive processes, expressive behavior and psychophysiological changes, what is another notable unemotional component?
With what unemotional component did William James identify emotion?
What emotional component did behaviorists not identify emotion with?
What academics did not identify emotions with physiological changes?
Who discussed emotions out of the context of expressive body actions and cultural labels?

context: Emotions involve different components, such as <b6_0>subjective experience<b6_0/>, cognitive processes, expressive behavior, psychophysiological changes, and <a0_0><b5_0><b7_0>instrumental behavior<b7_0/><b5_0/><a0_0/>. At one time, academics attempted to identify the emotion with one of the components: William James with a <a1_0>subjective experience<a1_0/>, behaviorists with <a2_0>instrumental behavior<a2_0/>, <a3_0>psychophysiologists<a3_0/> with physiological changes, and so on. More recently, emotion is said to consist of all the components. The different components of emotion are categorized somewhat differently depending on the academic discipline. In psychology and philosophy, emotion typically includes a subjective, conscious experience characterized primarily by <b8_0>psychophysiological<b8_0/> expressions, biological reactions, and mental states. A similar multicomponential description of emotion is found in sociology. For example, <a4_0><b9_0>Peggy Thoits<b9_0/><a4_0/> described emotions as involving physiological components, cultural or emotional labels (e.g., anger, surprise etc.), expressive body actions, and the appraisal of situations and contexts.
